trigger: Estrogen and progesterone induction of survival of monoblastoid cells undergoing <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced apoptosis .
Induction of apoptosis of mononucleated cells is a physiological process for regulating the intensity of the immune response .

The female steroid hormones estrogen ( E2 ) and progesterone ( Prog ) are known to modulate the reactivity of the immune system ; recently it has been demonstrated that they can regulate induction of apoptosis of endothelial cells and osteoblasts .
<extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated induction of apoptosis has been well characterized in myeloid cells .
We investigated whether E2 and Prog could interfere with <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced apoptosis of the monoblastoid U937 cell line .

Treatment with E2 or Prog increased survival and prevented apoptosis induced by <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in both undifferentiated and macrophage-like PMA-differentiated U937 cells , as assessed by trypan blue exclusion cell counting , thymidine incorporation , AnnexinV labeling , followed by flow cytometry and DNA fragmentation studies .

This effect can be associated with the activation of specific hormone receptors , since we observed the expression of the estrogen receptor alpha ( <extra_id_0> ER-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , <extra_id_0> ER-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> progesterone receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> PR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) mRNAs ; the <extra_id_0> ER-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein expression was confirmed by immunocytochemical analysis .

In addition , hormone - mediated survival against apoptosis was concentration dependent , reaching the half - maximal effect at 10 nM and blocked by the ER antagonist ICI 182 , 780 in undifferentiated cells , further supporting a receptor - mediated mechanism of cell survival .

Other steroid receptor drugs such as Raloxifene , RU486 , or the ICI 182 , 780 in PMA-differentiated cells displayed agonist activity by preventing <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced apoptosis as efficiently as the hormones alone , providing further evidence to the notion that steroid receptor drugs may manifest agonist or antagonist activities depending on the cellular context in which they are studied .

Treatment with E2 was also associated with a time - dependent decrease in the mRNA level of the proapoptotic Nip-2 protein , supporting the hypothesis that hormone responsiveness of U937 cells is mediated by target gene transcription .

Together , these results demonstrate that ER and <extra_id_0> PR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can be activated by endogenous or exogenous ligands to induce a genetic response that impairs <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced apoptosis in U937 cells .

The data presented here suggest that the female steroid receptors play a role in regulation of the immune response by preventing apoptosis of monoblastoid cells ; this effect might have important consequences in the clinical use of steroid receptor drugs .
